title: AN 1:21 Ekadhamma Suttas (AN 1:21–30, 39–40) | A Single Thing
summary: AN 1:21 Ekadhamma Suttas (AN 1:21–30, 39–40) | A Single Thing — Short statements on the importance of training one thing: the mind.

title: AN 1:45 Udakarahada Suttas (AN 1:45–46) | A Pool of Water
summary: AN 1:45 Udakarahada Suttas (AN 1:45–46) | A Pool of Water — The sullied and unsullied mind compared to a sullied and unsullied pond of water.

title: AN 1:48 Mudu Sutta | Soft
summary: AN 1:48 Mudu Sutta | Soft — A trained mind is pliant, like balsam.

title: AN 1:49 Lahu-parivaṭṭa Sutta | Quick to Reverse Itself
summary: AN 1:49 Lahu-parivaṭṭa Sutta | Quick to Reverse Itself — Even the Buddha, a master of analogies, couldn’t find an analogy for how quick the mind is to reverse itself.

title: AN 1:50 Pabhassara Suttas (AN 1:50–53) | Luminous
summary: AN 1:50 Pabhassara Suttas (AN 1:50–53) | Luminous — Discerning that the mind is luminous but invading by defilements enables you to develop it.

title: AN 1:140 Bahujanahitāya Sutta (AN 1:140–141) | For the Benefit of Many People
summary: AN 1:140 Bahujanahitāya Sutta (AN 1:140–141) | For the Benefit of Many People — It’s for the benefit of the world that Dhamma is explained as Dhamma, and not-Dhamma as not-Dhamma.

title: AN 1:329 Duggandha Sutta | Foul-smelling
summary: AN 1:329 Duggandha Sutta | Foul-smelling — Becoming compared to feces.

title: AN 2:5 Appaṭivāṇa Sutta | Relentlessly
summary: AN 2:5 Appaṭivāṇa Sutta | Relentlessly — The secret to the Buddha’s awakening: discontent with regard to skillful qualities and unrelenting exertion.

title: AN 2:9 Lokapāla Sutta | Guardians of the World
summary: AN 2:9 Lokapāla Sutta | Guardians of the World — Shame and compunction as guardians of the world.

title: AN 2:18 Ekaṁsena Sutta | Categorically
summary: AN 2:18 Ekaṁsena Sutta | Categorically — One of two teachings that the Buddha taught as categorically true across the board (the other is the four noble truths: see DN 9).

title: AN 2:19 Kusal’akusala Sutta | Skillful & Unskillful
summary: AN 2:19 Kusal’akusala Sutta | Skillful & Unskillful — “If it were not possible to abandon what is unskillful, I would not say to you, ‘Abandon what is unskillful.’”

title: AN 2:21 Bāla-paṇḍita Sutta | Fools & Wise People
summary: AN 2:21 Bāla-paṇḍita Sutta | Fools & Wise People — Foolish and wise ways of dealing with your own transgressions and those of others.

title: AN 2:23 Abhāsita Sutta | What Was Not Said
summary: AN 2:23 Abhāsita Sutta | What Was Not Said — To misquote the Buddha is to slander him.

title: AN 2:24 Neyyattha Sutta | A Meaning to be Inferred
summary: AN 2:24 Neyyattha Sutta | A Meaning to be Inferred — Two other ways of slandering the Buddha.

title: AN 2:29 Vijjā-bhāgiya Sutta | A Share in Clear Knowing
summary: AN 2:29 Vijjā-bhāgiya Sutta | A Share in Clear Knowing — Tranquility and insight, along with the purposes they serve.

title: AN 2:30 Vimutti Sutta | Release
summary: AN 2:30 Vimutti Sutta | Release — What brings about awareness-release and discernment-release.

title: AN 2:31 Kataññu Suttas (AN 2:31–32) | Gratitude
summary: AN 2:31 Kataññu Suttas (AN 2:31–32) | Gratitude — Two people who are not easy to repay: your mother and father.

title: AN 2:35 Samacitta Sutta | Like-minded
summary: AN 2:35 Samacitta Sutta | Like-minded — What it means to be fettered outside and fettered inside.

title: AN 2:36 Ārāmadaṇḍa Sutta | To Ārāmadaṇḍa
summary: AN 2:36 Ārāmadaṇḍa Sutta | To Ārāmadaṇḍa — Why lay people dispute with lay people; why contemplatives dispute with contemplatives.

title: AN 2:37 Kaṇḍarāyana Sutta | To Kaṇḍarāyana
summary: AN 2:37 Kaṇḍarāyana Sutta | To Kaṇḍarāyana — To be venerable is a matter, not of age, but of the mind’s freedom from sensuality.

title: AN 2:46 Ukkācita Sutta | Bombast
summary: AN 2:46 Ukkācita Sutta | Bombast — The difference between an assembly trained in bombast and one trained in cross-questioning.

title: AN 2:61 Sannivāsa Sutta | Communal Living
summary: AN 2:61 Sannivāsa Sutta | Communal Living — A bad community is one in which the members decide not to correct one another.

title: AN 2:74 Sukha Sutta | Pleasures
summary: AN 2:74 Sukha Sutta | Pleasures — The pleasure of equanimity is higher than the pleasure of enjoyment.

title: AN 2:99 Bāla Sutta | Fools
summary: AN 2:99 Bāla Sutta | Fools — A fool is reckoned by which kinds of burdens he picks up and which ones he doesn’t.

title: AN 2:118 Dullabhā Sutta | Hard to Find
summary: AN 2:118 Dullabhā Sutta | Hard to Find — People who are the first to do a kindness for you are hard to find, and so are worthy of gratitude.

title: AN 2:120 Duttappaya Sutta | Rarely Having Enough
summary: AN 2:120 Duttappaya Sutta | Rarely Having Enough — Two people who rarely have a sense of enough.

title: AN 2:123 Ghosa Suttas (AN 2:123–124) | Voice
summary: AN 2:123 Ghosa Suttas (AN 2:123–124) | Voice — The internal and external conditions for the arising of wrong view and right view.

title: AN 2:134 Ananuvicca Sutta | Without Investigating
summary: AN 2:134 Ananuvicca Sutta | Without Investigating — Investigate before settling on belief or disbelief.

title: AN 3:2 Lakkhaṇa Sutta | Characterized (by Action)
summary: AN 3:2 Lakkhaṇa Sutta | Characterized (by Action) — Fools and wise people are to be recognized by their bodily, verbal, and mental conduct.

title: AN 3:5 Ayoniso Sutta | Inappropriately
summary: AN 3:5 Ayoniso Sutta | Inappropriately — People can be recognized as foolish or wise by the way they formulate and answer questions, and by whether they acknowledge when a question has received an appropriate response.

title: AN 3:10 Mala Sutta | Impurities
summary: AN 3:10 Mala Sutta | Impurities — Qualities that can create a hell or a heaven in this very lifetime.

title: AN 3:15 Pacetana Sutta | The Chariot Maker
summary: AN 3:15 Pacetana Sutta | The Chariot Maker — The Buddha, recounting one of his previous lives in which he was an expert chariot maker, uses the chariot maker’s skills as an analogy for his current skills as a trainer of monks and nuns.

title: AN 3:20 Pāpaṇika Sutta | The Shopkeeper
summary: AN 3:20 Pāpaṇika Sutta | The Shopkeeper — How a good monk is like a good shopkeeper.

title: AN 3:22 Gilāna Sutta | Sick People
summary: AN 3:22 Gilāna Sutta | Sick People — Why the Buddha teaches even those who will gain awakening without his teaching, and those who won’t even when he teaches them.

title: AN 3:24 Bahukāra Sutta | Great Benefactors
summary: AN 3:24 Bahukāra Sutta | Great Benefactors — One’s three greatest benefactors.

title: AN 3:30 Avakujja Sutta | Upside Down
summary: AN 3:30 Avakujja Sutta | Upside Down — Pay attention to a Dhamma talk, both during the talk and afterwards.

title: AN 3:32 Ānanda Sutta | To Ven. Ānanda
summary: AN 3:32 Ānanda Sutta | To Ven. Ānanda — The Buddha explains a passage from Sn 5:3 by describing a state of concentration free from I-making and mine-making.

title: AN 3:33 Sāriputta Sutta | To Ven. Sāriputta
summary: AN 3:33 Sāriputta Sutta | To Ven. Sāriputta — The Buddha explains a passage from Sn 5:13 by describing a state of concentration free from I-making and mine-making.

title: AN 3:34 Nidāna Sutta | Causes
summary: AN 3:34 Nidāna Sutta | Causes — An action (kamma) performed by an arahant bears no kammic fruit. This sutta explains why.

title: AN 3:35 Hatthaka Sutta | To Hatthaka
summary: AN 3:35 Hatthaka Sutta | To Hatthaka — The state of the mind, rather than the comfort of the bed, determines who gets a good night’s sleep.

title: AN 3:39 Sukhamāla Sutta | Refinement
summary: AN 3:39 Sukhamāla Sutta | Refinement — The Buddha recalls how, as a young man living in extreme refinement, he overcame intoxication with youth, health, and life.

title: AN 3:40 Ādhipateyya Sutta | Governing Principles
summary: AN 3:40 Ādhipateyya Sutta | Governing Principles — How to use thoughts of self, the world, and the Dhamma as motivating factors to stick with the path.

title: AN 3:42 Ṭhāna Sutta | Instances
summary: AN 3:42 Ṭhāna Sutta | Instances — How conviction shows in one’s actions.

title: AN 3:47 Saṅkhata Sutta (AN 3:47–48) | Fabricated
summary: AN 3:47 Saṅkhata Sutta (AN 3:47–48) | Fabricated — The defining characteristics of what’s fabricated and what’s unfabricated.

title: AN 3:49 Pabbata Sutta | A Mountain
summary: AN 3:49 Pabbata Sutta | A Mountain — Three ways in which the descendents of a person of conviction prosper.

title: AN 3:50 Ātappa Sutta | Ardency
summary: AN 3:50 Ātappa Sutta | Ardency — When to exercise ardency.

title: AN 3:52 Dvejana Sutta | Two People (1)
summary: AN 3:52 Dvejana Sutta | Two People (1) — The Buddha teaches restraint and merit-making to two aged brahmans who have no good deeds to look back on: “Keeping sight of this danger in death, do merit-deeds that bring bliss.”

title: AN 3:53 Dvejana Sutta | Two People (2)
summary: AN 3:53 Dvejana Sutta | Two People (2) — The Buddha teaches restraint and generosity to two aged brahmans who have no good deeds to look back on: “When a house is aflame, the vessel salvaged is the one that will be of use, not the one left there to burn.”

title: AN 3:58 Vaccha Sutta | To Vaccha (on Giving)
summary: AN 3:58 Vaccha Sutta | To Vaccha (on Giving) — Whoever prevents another from giving a gift creates three obstructions: an obstruction to the merit of the giver, an obstruction to the recipient’s gains, and prior to that he undermines and harms his own self.

title: AN 3:61 Saṅgārava Sutta | To Saṅgārava
summary: AN 3:61 Saṅgārava Sutta | To Saṅgārava — Do the practices of merit-making and going-forth benefit only the person who does them?

title: AN 3:62 Tittha Sutta | Sectarians
summary: AN 3:62 Tittha Sutta | Sectarians — In a rare instance where the Buddha seeks out other sectarians to argue with them, he confronts three doctrines that, remaining stuck in a doctrine of inaction, leave their adherents unprotected from the impulse to engage in unskillful action: the belief that everything experienced is the result of old actions (a belief, ironically, frequently attributed to the Buddha himself), the belief that everything experienced is the result of a supreme being’s act of creation, and the belief that everything experienced is without cause.

title: AN 3:63 Bhaya Sutta | Dangers
summary: AN 3:63 Bhaya Sutta | Dangers — Three false and three genuine mother-&-child-separating dangers.

title: AN 3:66 Kālāma Sutta | To the Kālāmas
summary: AN 3:66 Kālāma Sutta | To the Kālāmas — The Buddha’s standards for judging whether a teaching should be rejected or adopted.

title: AN 3:68 Kathāvatthu Sutta | Topics for Discussion
summary: AN 3:68 Kathāvatthu Sutta | Topics for Discussion — Standards for judging whether a person is fit to talk with: a useful series of reflections for when you find yourself debating unprincipled people.

title: AN 3:69 Titthiya Sutta | Sectarians
summary: AN 3:69 Titthiya Sutta | Sectarians — The distinguishing characteristics among passion, aversion, and delusion; how they arise, and how they can be abandoned.

title: AN 3:70 Mūla Sutta | Roots
summary: AN 3:70 Mūla Sutta | Roots — The three roots of unskillful behavior, the three roots of skillful behavior, and how acting on the desire for power leads a person deeper into the unskillful roots, whereas not acting on that desire makes it easier to develop the skillful roots.

title: AN 3:71 Mūluposatha Sutta | The Roots of the Uposatha
summary: AN 3:71 Mūluposatha Sutta | The Roots of the Uposatha — Three ways of observing the uposatha: like a cowherd, like a Jain, and like a noble one.

title: AN 3:72 Channa Sutta | To Channa the Wanderer
summary: AN 3:72 Channa Sutta | To Channa the Wanderer — A wanderer asks Ven. Ānanda why he teaches the abandoning of passion, aversion, and delusion.

title: AN 3:73 Ājīvaka Sutta | To the Fatalists’ Student
summary: AN 3:73 Ājīvaka Sutta | To the Fatalists’ Student — A follower of another teacher asks Ven. Ānanda, “Among us, sir, whose Dhamma is well-taught? Who has practiced well in this world? Who in the world is Well-Gone?” In response, Ven. Ānanda gets the man to answer his own question: an excellent example of Ven. Ānanda’s skill in answering questions.

title: AN 3:74 Sakka Sutta | To the Sakyan
summary: AN 3:74 Sakka Sutta | To the Sakyan — By discussing the distinction between the virtue, concentration, and discernment of one in training and the virtue, concentration, and discernment of one whose training is complete, Ven. Ānanda answers the question, “Does concentration come first, and knowledge after, or does knowledge come first, and concentration after?”

title: AN 3:77 Bhava Sutta | Becoming (1)
summary: AN 3:77 Bhava Sutta | Becoming (1) — Using the analogy of the field, the seed, and moisture, the Buddha explains the arising of the three levels of becoming.

title: AN 3:78 Bhava Sutta | Becoming (2)
summary: AN 3:78 Bhava Sutta | Becoming (2) — A slightly different explanation of the arising of the three levels of becoming.

title: AN 3:79 Sīlabbata Sutta | Habit & Practice
summary: AN 3:79 Sīlabbata Sutta | Habit & Practice — Is every kind of practice fruitful? Ven Ānanda gives an analytical answer.

title: AN 3:83 Gadrabha Sutta | The Donkey
summary: AN 3:83 Gadrabha Sutta | The Donkey — What makes a monk a genuine monk.

title: AN 3:85 Vajjiputta Sutta | The Vajjian Monk
summary: AN 3:85 Vajjiputta Sutta | The Vajjian Monk — A monk complains to the Buddha that he cannot train in all the many rules of the Pāṭimokkha. The Buddha recommends that he focus instead on the three trainings, under which all those rules are gathered.

title: AN 3:87 Sekhin Sutta (1) | One in Training
summary: AN 3:87 Sekhin Sutta (1) | One in Training — The attainments of a stream-enterer, a non-returner, and an arahant measured in terms of their mastery of virtue, concentration, and discernment.

title: AN 3:88 Sekhin Sutta (2) | One in Training
summary: AN 3:88 Sekhin Sutta (2) | One in Training — An expansion of the preceding sutta, in which the various grades of stream-enterer and non-returner are listed.

title: AN 3:90 Sikkha Sutta | Trainings (1)
summary: AN 3:90 Sikkha Sutta | Trainings (1) — The three trainings—in heightened virtue, heightened mind, and heightened discernment—defined.

title: AN 3:91 Sikkha Sutta | Trainings (2)
summary: AN 3:91 Sikkha Sutta | Trainings (2) — The three trainings defined again, with a slightly different definition given for the training in heightened discernment.

title: AN 3:93 Accāyika Sutta | Urgent
summary: AN 3:93 Accāyika Sutta | Urgent — The urgent duties of a monk compared to the urgent duties of a farmer.

title: AN 3:95 Sarada Sutta | Autumn
summary: AN 3:95 Sarada Sutta | Autumn — What happens if a noble disciple dies while practicing jhāna.

title: AN 3:96 Parisā Sutta | Assemblies
summary: AN 3:96 Parisā Sutta | Assemblies — Three types of monastic communities, two of them conducive to awakening.

title: AN 3:97 Ājāniya Sutta | The Thoroughbred
summary: AN 3:97 Ājāniya Sutta | The Thoroughbred — The Buddha explains how a monk, like a thoroughbred horse, can be consummate in beauty, strength, and speed.

title: AN 3:101 Loṇaphala Sutta | The Salt Crystal
summary: AN 3:101 Loṇaphala Sutta | The Salt Crystal — Three analogies to explain why an unskillful deed done by one person can lead that person to hell, while the same deed done by another person may hardly be felt at all. An important sutta for explaining why past kamma does not fully account for what is felt in the present moment. Present kamma plays an important role as well.

title: AN 3:102 Paṁsudhovaka Sutta | The Dirt-washer
summary: AN 3:102 Paṁsudhovaka Sutta | The Dirt-washer — The skills of concentration compared to the skills of a gold-washer.

title: AN 3:103 Nimitta Sutta | Themes
summary: AN 3:103 Nimitta Sutta | Themes — Using the analogy of a goldsmith, the Buddha explains why concentration practice should alternate, when appropriate, among three themes: the theme of concentration, the theme of uplifted energy, and the theme of equanimity.

title: AN 3:109 Atitta Sutta | No Satiation
summary: AN 3:109 Atitta Sutta | No Satiation — Despite what your defilements might tell you, you can never reach the point of enough through indulging in three things.

title: AN 3:110 Kuta Sutta | The Peak of the Roof
summary: AN 3:110 Kuta Sutta | The Peak of the Roof — How protecting the mind keeps you from getting soggy.

title: AN 3:112 Nidāna Sutta | Causes (1)
summary: AN 3:112 Nidāna Sutta | Causes (1) — The causes for skillful and unskillful action.

title: AN 3:113 Nidāna Sutta | Causes (2)
summary: AN 3:113 Nidāna Sutta | Causes (2) — You can free yourself from the fetter of passion by discerning the future results of allowing yourself to get fettered.

title: AN 3:115 Dullabha Sutta | Rare
summary: AN 3:115 Dullabha Sutta | Rare — Three people who are hard to find.

title: AN 3:116 Appameyya Sutta | Immeasurable
summary: AN 3:116 Appameyya Sutta | Immeasurable — People who are easy to measure, hard to measure, & those who can’t be measured at all.

title: AN 3:117 Aneñjaka Sutta | Imperturbable
summary: AN 3:117 Aneñjaka Sutta | Imperturbable — What happens after death to those who attain imperturbable concentration.

title: AN 3:121 Soceyya Sutta | Purities (1)
summary: AN 3:121 Soceyya Sutta | Purities (1) — Purity on the mundane level defined.

title: AN 3:122 Soceyya Sutta | Purities (2)
summary: AN 3:122 Soceyya Sutta | Purities (2) — Purity on the transcendent level defined.

title: AN 3:123 Moneyya Sutta | Sagacity
summary: AN 3:123 Moneyya Sutta | Sagacity — Three types of sagacity—bodily, verbal, and mental—defined. This sutta is apparently the “sagacity” sutta that King Asoka advised monks, nuns, lay men, and lay women to listen to frequently and to ponder so that the True Dhamma will last a long time.

title: AN 3:124 Kusināra Sutta | At Kusināra
summary: AN 3:124 Kusināra Sutta | At Kusināra — When a monk receives food at an invitational meal, the rewards for the donor depend, at least in part, on the monk’s attitude toward the food.

title: AN 3:126 Gotamaka-cetiya Sutta | At Gotamaka Shrine
summary: AN 3:126 Gotamaka-cetiya Sutta | At Gotamaka Shrine — The fact that the Buddha teaches through direct knowledge, with cause, and with marvels (see AN 3:61) is reason enough to take joy in the Buddha, Dhamma, and Saṅgha.

title: AN 3:129 Kaṭuviya Sutta | Putrid
summary: AN 3:129 Kaṭuviya Sutta | Putrid — “Monk, monk, don’t let yourself putrefy! On one who lets himself putrefy & stink with the stench of carrion, there’s no way that flies won’t swarm & attack!”

title: AN 3:131 Anuruddha Sutta | To Anuruddha
summary: AN 3:131 Anuruddha Sutta | To Anuruddha — The defilements that can potentially surround the attainments of concentration and supranormal powers, and get in the way of awakening.

title: AN 3:133 Lekha Sutta | Inscriptions
summary: AN 3:133 Lekha Sutta | Inscriptions — Three types of individuals: one like an inscription in rock, one like an inscription in soil, and one like an inscription in water.

title: AN 3:136 Mitta Sutta | A Friend
summary: AN 3:136 Mitta Sutta | A Friend — Qualities of a friend to be treasured.

title: AN 3:137 Dhamma-niyāma Sutta | The Orderliness of the Dhamma
summary: AN 3:137 Dhamma-niyāma Sutta | The Orderliness of the Dhamma — Truths that are true regardless of whether the Buddha has pointed them out: All fabrications are inconstant; all fabrications are stressful; all phenomena are not-self.

title: AN 4:1 Anubuddha Sutta | Understanding
summary: AN 4:1 Anubuddha Sutta | Understanding — “It’s because of not understanding and not penetrating noble virtue… noble concentration… noble discernment… noble release that we have transmigrated & wandered on for such a long, long time, you & I.”

title: AN 4:5 Anusota Sutta | With the Flow
summary: AN 4:5 Anusota Sutta | With the Flow — How going with the flow is not a good thing.

title: AN 4:10 Yoga Sutta | Yokes
summary: AN 4:10 Yoga Sutta | Yokes — In many discourses, the Buddha speaks of “the unexcelled rest from the yoke.” In this discourse he explains what yokes he is referring to, and how that rest comes about.

title: AN 4:19 Agati Sutta | Off Course
summary: AN 4:19 Agati Sutta | Off Course — Four states of mind—desire, aversion, delusion, and fear—that the Vinaya often cites as leading to unfair and biased behavior.

title: AN 4:24 Kāḷaka Sutta | At Kāḷaka’s Park
summary: AN 4:24 Kāḷaka Sutta | At Kāḷaka’s Park — The Buddha explains how, despite his wide range of knowledge, he is “Such” with regard to all that he knows: He is not fastened to that knowledge, and it is not established in him.

title: AN 4:28 Ariya-vaṁsa Sutta | The Traditions of the Noble Ones
summary: AN 4:28 Ariya-vaṁsa Sutta | The Traditions of the Noble Ones — Like any good family, the “family” of the noble ones has its fine traditions. These traditions are special, however, in that they lie outside the culture of any nation, and they lead to conquest, not over others, but over displeasure within. (This is one of the suttas that King Asoka advised monks, nuns, lay men, and lay women to listen to frequently and to ponder so that the True Dhamma will last a long time.)

title: AN 4:31 Cakka Sutta | Wheels
summary: AN 4:31 Cakka Sutta | Wheels — Four qualities that lead to an abundance of wealth.

title: AN 4:32 Saṅgaha Sutta | The Bonds of Fellowship
summary: AN 4:32 Saṅgaha Sutta | The Bonds of Fellowship — Four qualities that act as a linchpin in holding societies and families together.

title: AN 4:33 Sīha Sutta | The Lion
summary: AN 4:33 Sīha Sutta | The Lion — The terror that the Buddha’s teaching on self-identification inspires in the heavenly worlds.

title: AN 4:35 Vassakāra Sutta | With Vassakāra
summary: AN 4:35 Vassakāra Sutta | With Vassakāra — A discussion between Vassakāra the brahman and the Buddha as to the four qualities that entitle a person to be called great and discerning.

title: AN 4:36 Doṇa Sutta | With Doṇa
summary: AN 4:36 Doṇa Sutta | With Doṇa — The Buddha, asked whether he is a deva, a spirit, or a human being, replies that he is simply “awake.”

title: AN 4:37 Aparihāni Sutta | No Falling Away
summary: AN 4:37 Aparihāni Sutta | No Falling Away — Four qualities that make a monk incapable of falling away, and bring him in the presence of unbinding.

title: AN 4:38 Paṭilīna Sutta | Detached
summary: AN 4:38 Paṭilīna Sutta | Detached — What it means to be detached in body and mind.

title: AN 4:41 Samādhi Sutta | Concentration
summary: AN 4:41 Samādhi Sutta | Concentration — Four purposes to which right concentration can be applied: a pleasant abiding here-&-now, mindfulness and alertness, psychic powers, and the ending of the effluents.

title: AN 4:42 Pañha Sutta | Questions
summary: AN 4:42 Pañha Sutta | Questions — The Buddha classifies questions into four types in terms of the strategy of response that they deserve.

title: AN 4:45 Rohitassa Sutta | To Rohitassa
summary: AN 4:45 Rohitassa Sutta | To Rohitassa — How the end of the cosmos is to be found within.

title: AN 4:49 Vipallāsa Sutta | Perversions
summary: AN 4:49 Vipallāsa Sutta | Perversions — Four perversions of perception: perceiving what is inconstant to be constant, what is stressful to be pleasant, what is not-self to be self, and what is unattractive as attractive.

title: AN 4:50 Upakkilesa Sutta | Obscurations
summary: AN 4:50 Upakkilesa Sutta | Obscurations — Four types of unskillful behavior that cause a contemplative not to shine.

title: AN 4:55 Samajivina Sutta | Living in Tune
summary: AN 4:55 Samajivina Sutta | Living in Tune — How to behave if you want to live together with your spouse even after death.

title: AN 4:62 Anaṇa Sutta | Debtlessness
summary: AN 4:62 Anaṇa Sutta | Debtlessness — The bliss of blamelessness is worth far more than the bliss of having, partaking, and being debtless.

title: AN 4:67 Ahinā Sutta | By a Snake
summary: AN 4:67 Ahinā Sutta | By a Snake — A charm, whose power is based on goodwill, for protection from snakes and other creeping things.

title: AN 4:73 Sappurisa Sutta | A Person of Integrity
summary: AN 4:73 Sappurisa Sutta | A Person of Integrity — One can be recognized as a person of integrity based on how one discusses one’s own faults and good qualities, and the faults and good qualities of others.

title: AN 4:77 Acintita Sutta | Inconceivable
summary: AN 4:77 Acintita Sutta | Inconceivable — Four inconceivables that would bring madness to anyone who tried to conjecture about them.

title: AN 4:79 Vaṇijja Sutta | Trade
summary: AN 4:79 Vaṇijja Sutta | Trade — Reasons why some people succeed in business and others, engaged in the same business, don’t.

title: AN 4:85 Tama Sutta | Darkness
summary: AN 4:85 Tama Sutta | Darkness — Four types of individuals: one born in darkness and headed for darkness, one born in darkness and headed for light, one born in light and headed for darkness, and one born in light and headed for light

title: AN 4:87 Putta Sutta | The Son
summary: AN 4:87 Putta Sutta | The Son — Four levels of genuine contemplatives.

title: AN 4:88 Saññojana Sutta | Fetters
summary: AN 4:88 Saññojana Sutta | Fetters — A second way of defining four levels of genuine contemplatives.

title: AN 4:89 Diṭṭhi Sutta | View
summary: AN 4:89 Diṭṭhi Sutta | View — A third way of defining four levels of genuine contemplatives.

title: AN 4:90 Khandha Sutta | Aggregates
summary: AN 4:90 Khandha Sutta | Aggregates — A fourth way of defining four levels of genuine contemplatives.

title: AN 4:94 Samādhi Sutta | Concentration (Tranquility & Insight)
summary: AN 4:94 Samādhi Sutta | Concentration (Tranquility & Insight) — Four types of individuals—one with tranquility but no insight, one with insight but no tranquility, one with neither, and one with both—and how they should practice.

title: AN 4:95 Chalāvāta Sutta | The Firebrand
summary: AN 4:95 Chalāvāta Sutta | The Firebrand — The Buddha ranks four types of individuals: one who practices for his/her own benefit and the benefit of others; one who practices for his/her own benefit but not for the benefit others; one who practices for the benefit of others but not for his/her own; and one who practices neither for his/her own benefit nor for the benefit of others.

title: AN 4:96 Rāga-vinaya Sutta | The Subduing of Passion
summary: AN 4:96 Rāga-vinaya Sutta | The Subduing of Passion — A definition of what it means—in light of the teachings of kamma—to practice for one’s own benefit and for the benefit of others.

title: AN 4:99 Sikkhā Sutta | Trainings
summary: AN 4:99 Sikkhā Sutta | Trainings — Another definition of what it means—in light of the teachings of kamma—to practice for one’s own benefit and for the benefit of others.

title: AN 4:100 Potaliya Sutta | To Potaliya
summary: AN 4:100 Potaliya Sutta | To Potaliya — Which is more excellent: Staying equanimous and silent, or knowing when to speak criticism and praise?

title: AN 4:102 Valāhaka Sutta | Thunderheads
summary: AN 4:102 Valāhaka Sutta | Thunderheads — Four types of individuals: one who thunders but doesn’t rain, one who rains but doesn’t thunder, one who neither thunders nor rains, and one who both thunders and rains.

title: AN 4:111 Kesi Sutta | To Kesin the Horsetrainer
summary: AN 4:111 Kesi Sutta | To Kesin the Horsetrainer — The Buddha compares the way he trains monks to the way a horse-trainer trains horses. A corrective to the common misperception that the Buddha’s teaching style was always mild.

title: AN 4:113 Patoda Sutta | The Goad-stick
summary: AN 4:113 Patoda Sutta | The Goad-stick — Four types of students compared to four types of thoroughbred horses, based on how closely they have to be touched by suffering before being stirred to practice.

title: AN 4:115 Ṭhāna Sutta | Courses of Action
summary: AN 4:115 Ṭhāna Sutta | Courses of Action — Four courses of action, two of which—what is unpleasant to do but leads to what is profitable, and what is pleasant to do but leads to what is unprofitable—are tests of one’s discernment.

title: AN 4:116 Appamāda Sutta | Heedfulness
summary: AN 4:116 Appamāda Sutta | Heedfulness — How to avoid fear of where you will be reborn.

title: AN 4:117 Ārakkha Sutta | Guarding
summary: AN 4:117 Ārakkha Sutta | Guarding — Guarding your mind brings freedom from fear.

title: AN 4:123 Jhāna Sutta | Mental Absorption (1)
summary: AN 4:123 Jhāna Sutta | Mental Absorption (1) — The levels of rebirth to which mastery of each of the four jhānas can lead, along with the subsequent course of one who is an educated disciple of the noble ones contrasted with the subsequent course of one who is not.

title: AN 4:124 Jhāna Sutta | Mental Absorption (2)
summary: AN 4:124 Jhāna Sutta | Mental Absorption (2) — How mastery of any of the four jhānas, together with an analysis of those jhānas in terms of insight, can lead to rebirth in the Pure Abodes.

title: AN 4:125 Mettā Sutta | Goodwill (1)
summary: AN 4:125 Mettā Sutta | Goodwill (1) — The levels of rebirth to which mastery of each of the four brahmavihāras can lead, along with the subsequent course of one who is an educated disciple of the noble ones contrasted with the subsequent course of one who is not.

title: AN 4:126 Mettā Sutta | Goodwill (2)
summary: AN 4:126 Mettā Sutta | Goodwill (2) — How mastery of any of the four brahmavihāras, together with an analysis of those brahmavihāras in terms of insight, can lead to rebirth in the Pure Abodes.

title: AN 4:128 Abbhūta Sutta | Astounding
summary: AN 4:128 Abbhūta Sutta | Astounding — When the Buddha appears, people want to listen to the Dhamma that goes against their usual inclinations.

title: AN 4:131 Saṁyojana Sutta | Fetters
summary: AN 4:131 Saṁyojana Sutta | Fetters — Once-returners, two types of non-returners, and arahants, analyzed in terms of the fetters they have and haven’t abandoned.

title: AN 4:138 Nikkaṭṭha Sutta | Withdrawn
summary: AN 4:138 Nikkaṭṭha Sutta | Withdrawn — Living in the seclusion of the wilderness isn’t necessarily a sign that your mind is secluded.

title: AN 4:144 Obhāsa Sutta | Brightness
summary: AN 4:144 Obhāsa Sutta | Brightness — The brightness of discernment outshines the brightness of the sun, the moon, and fire.

title: AN 4:156 Kappa Sutta | An Eon
summary: AN 4:156 Kappa Sutta | An Eon — What are the parts of an eon, and how long are they?

title: AN 4:158 Parihāni Sutta | Decline
summary: AN 4:158 Parihāni Sutta | Decline — How to recognize whether you are declining in the practice.

title: AN 4:159 Bhikkhunī Sutta | The Nun
summary: AN 4:159 Bhikkhunī Sutta | The Nun — Ven. Ānanda teaches a nun that although food can be used to lead to the abandoning of food, craving to lead to the abandoning of craving, and conceit to lead to the abandoning of conceit, the same principle doesn’t apply to sexual intercourse.

title: AN 4:160 Sugata Sutta | The One Well-gone
summary: AN 4:160 Sugata Sutta | The One Well-gone — What causes the True Dhamma to disappear? What causes it to remain?

title: AN 4:162 Vitthāra Sutta | (Modes of Practice) in Detail
summary: AN 4:162 Vitthāra Sutta | (Modes of Practice) in Detail — Four modes of practice—painful with slow intuition, painful with quick intuition, pleasant with slow intuition, and pleasant with quick intuition—defined.

title: AN 4:163 Asubha Sutta | Unattractiveness
summary: AN 4:163 Asubha Sutta | Unattractiveness — Alternative definitions for the modes of practice defined in the preceding sutta.

title: AN 4:164 Khama Sutta | Tolerant (1)
summary: AN 4:164 Khama Sutta | Tolerant (1) — Four modes of practice: intolerant, tolerant, self-controlled, and even.

title: AN 4:165 Khama Sutta | Tolerant (2)
summary: AN 4:165 Khama Sutta | Tolerant (2) — The same four modes of practice listed in the preceding sutta, but with alternative definitions for intolerant and tolerant practice.

title: AN 4:170 Yuganaddha Sutta | In Tandem
summary: AN 4:170 Yuganaddha Sutta | In Tandem — Four paths of practice to arahantship: insight preceded by tranquility, tranquility preceded by insight, tranquility and insight developed in tandem, and concentration attained after restlessness concerning the Dhamma has been brought under control.

title: AN 4:173 Koṭṭhita Sutta | To Koṭṭhita
summary: AN 4:173 Koṭṭhita Sutta | To Koṭṭhita — Ven. Mahā Koṭṭhita asks Ven. Sāriputta: “With the remainderless fading & cessation of the six contact-media, is it the case that there is anything else? …nothing else? …both? …neither?” Ven. Sāriputta, explains why none of these alternatives is the case.

title: AN 4:178 Jambālī Sutta | The Waste-water Pool
summary: AN 4:178 Jambālī Sutta | The Waste-water Pool — The jhānas and brahmavihāras, on their own, do not automatically lead to the cessation of self-identification or ignorance.

title: AN 4:179 Nibbāna Sutta | Unbinding
summary: AN 4:179 Nibbāna Sutta | Unbinding — It’s because they do or don’t discern the consequences of four types of perceptions that some beings attain unbinding in the present life, and some don’t.

title: AN 4:181 Yodhājīva Sutta | The Professional Warrior
summary: AN 4:181 Yodhājīva Sutta | The Professional Warrior — Four qualities of an excellent monk that parallel four qualities of an expert archer.

title: AN 4:182 Pāṭibhoga Sutta | Guarantor
summary: AN 4:182 Pāṭibhoga Sutta | Guarantor — Four things for which you can find no guarantor.

title: AN 4:183 Suta Sutta | On What is Heard
summary: AN 4:183 Suta Sutta | On What is Heard — Four types of things that should not be spoken about, even if one knows or believes them to be true.

title: AN 4:184 Abhaya Sutta | Fearless
summary: AN 4:184 Abhaya Sutta | Fearless — Four reasons why some people fear death and others don’t.

title: AN 4:191 Sotānugata Sutta | Followed by Ear
summary: AN 4:191 Sotānugata Sutta | Followed by Ear — The rewards of memorizing and contemplating the Dhamma.

title: AN 4:192 Ṭhāna Sutta | Traits
summary: AN 4:192 Ṭhāna Sutta | Traits — How to know another person’s virtue, purity, endurance, and discernment.

title: AN 4:194 Sāpuga Sutta | At Sāpuga

This sutta not only explains why, but also shows how love born of love, aversion born of love, love born of aversion, and aversion born of aversion can be overcome, along with the rewards of overcoming these things.

title: AN 4:201 Sikkhāpada Sutta | Training Rules
summary: AN 4:201 Sikkhāpada Sutta | Training Rules — It’s bad enough when you break the precepts. It’s even worse when you get others to break them, too. It’s good when you keep the precepts, and even better to encourage others to keep them, too.

title: AN 4:237 Ariyamagga Sutta | The Noble Path
summary: AN 4:237 Ariyamagga Sutta | The Noble Path — Bright kamma, dark kamma, kamma that is both bright and dark, and kamma that is neither bright nor dark, and that leads to the end of kamma.

title: AN 4:245 Sikkhā Sutta | Training

title: AN 4:252 Pariyesanā Sutta | Searches
summary: AN 4:252 Pariyesanā Sutta | Searches — Four ignoble searches and four noble searches.

title: AN 4:263 Araññaka Sutta | A Wilderness Dweller
summary: AN 4:263 Araññaka Sutta | A Wilderness Dweller — Four qualities that make a monk fit to dwell in isolated wilderness dwellings.

title: AN 5:2 Vitthata Sutta (Strengths) | In Detail
summary: AN 5:2 Vitthata Sutta (Strengths) | In Detail — Five strengths for one in training: conviction, a sense of shame, a sense of compunction, persistence, and discernment.

title: AN 5:74 Dhammavihārin Sutta | Dwelling in the Dhamma (2)
summary: AN 5:74 Dhammavihārin Sutta | Dwelling in the Dhamma (2) — Another explanation of what it means to have the Dhamma as your home.

title: AN 5:76 Yodhājīva Sutta | The Professional Warrior (2)
summary: AN 5:76 Yodhājīva Sutta | The Professional Warrior (2) — Another sutta in which the Buddha compares the victorious monk to a victorious warrior.

title: AN 5:78 Anāgata-bhayāni Sutta | Future Dangers (2)

title: AN 5:80 Anāgata-bhayāni Sutta | Future Dangers (4)
summary: AN 5:80 Anāgata-bhayāni Sutta | Future Dangers (4) — This sutta advises reflecting on the dangers of the future luxury of the Saṅgha as a goad to practice.

title: AN 5:106 Phāsu Sutta | Comfortably
summary: AN 5:106 Phāsu Sutta | Comfortably — How can a monk live peacefully in a community of monks?

title: AN 5:109 Catuddisa Sutta | [A Monk] of the Four Directions
summary: AN 5:109 Catuddisa Sutta | [A Monk] of the Four Directions — How to be at home everywhere.

title: AN 5:110 Arañña Sutta | Wilderness
summary: AN 5:110 Arañña Sutta | Wilderness — The qualities needed for living in isolation in the wilderness.

summary: AN 5:114 Andhakavinda Sutta | At Andhakavinda — Newly ordained monks should be encouraged to develop these five qualities.

summary: AN 5:121 Gilāna Sutta | To One Who Is Sick — Five perceptions that, when held to, help a weak or sickly monk to gain full release.

title: AN 5:137 Appaṁ Supati Sutta | One Sleeps Little
summary: AN 5:137 Appaṁ Supati Sutta | One Sleeps Little — Five people who get little sleep at night.

summary: AN 5:139 Akkhama Sutta | Not Resilient — Five qualities in a monk compared to five parallel qualities in an elephant gone into battle.

title: AN 5:140 Sotar Sutta | The Listener
summary: AN 5:140 Sotar Sutta | The Listener — Another list of five qualities in a monk compared to five parallel qualities in an elephant gone into battle.

title: AN 5:148 Sappurisadāna Sutta | A Person of Integrity’s Gifts
summary: AN 5:148 Sappurisadāna Sutta | A Person of Integrity’s Gifts — Five qualities of a gift made by a person on integrity—giving with a sense of conviction, attentively, in season, with an empathetic heart, and without adversely affecting oneself or others—and the rewards of giving in these ways.

title: AN 5:151 Saddhamma-niyāma Sutta | Assuredness in the True Dhamma (1)
summary: AN 5:151 Saddhamma-niyāma Sutta | Assuredness in the True Dhamma (1) — Five ways of listening to a Dhamma talk that will determine whether you can alight on the True Dhamma while listening.

title: AN 5:152 Saddhamma-niyāma Sutta | Assuredness in the True Dhamma (2)
summary: AN 5:152 Saddhamma-niyāma Sutta | Assuredness in the True Dhamma (2) — Another list of five ways of listening to a Dhamma talk that will determine whether you can alight on the True Dhamma while listening.

title: AN 5:159 Udāyin Sutta | About Udāyin (On Teaching the Dhamma)
summary: AN 5:159 Udāyin Sutta | About Udāyin (On Teaching the Dhamma) — Five attitudes that should be established in a person teaching the Dhamma.

title: AN 5:161 Āghatāvinaya Sutta | The Subduing of Hatred (1)
summary: AN 5:161 Āghatāvinaya Sutta | The Subduing of Hatred (1) — Five reflections that help to subdue hatred.

summary: AN 5:162 Āghātavinaya Sutta | The Subduing of Hatred (2) — Another list of five reflections for subduing hatred.

summary: AN 5:165 Pañhapucchā Sutta | On Asking Questions — Five motivations for asking questions.

title: AN 5:191 Soṇa Sutta | The Dog Discourse
summary: AN 5:191 Soṇa Sutta | The Dog Discourse — The Buddha compares brahmans with dogs, and the dogs come out better in the comparison. An example of how pointed the Buddha’s sense of humor could be.

title: AN 5:196 Supina Sutta | Dreams
summary: AN 5:196 Supina Sutta | Dreams — Five prophetic dreams that appeared to the Buddha prior to his awakening.

title: AN 5:198 Vācā Sutta | A Statement
summary: AN 5:198 Vācā Sutta | A Statement — Five characteristics of a well-spoken statement.

title: AN 5:199 Kula Sutta | A Family
summary: AN 5:199 Kula Sutta | A Family — When a virtuous person who has gone forth approaches a family, the people there give rise to a great deal of merit by five means.

title: AN 5:200 Nissāraṇīya Sutta | Leading to Escape
summary: AN 5:200 Nissāraṇīya Sutta | Leading to Escape — Five means of escape: from sensuality, from ill will, harmfulness, forms, and self-identification.

summary: AN 5:202 Dhammassavana Sutta | Listening to the Dhamma — Five rewards of listening to the Dhamma.

title: AN 6:12 Sārāṇīya Sutta | Conducive to Amiability
summary: AN 6:12 Sārāṇīya Sutta | Conducive to Amiability — Six conditions that lead to harmony in a group.

title: AN 6:13 Nissāraṇīya Sutta | Means of Escape

summary: AN 6:41 Dārukkhandha Sutta | The Wood Pile — The properties or potentials in a material object that allow a monk with psychic powers to will that it be nothing but earth, water, fire, wind, beautiful, or unattractive.

title: AN 6:42 Nāgita Sutta | To Nāgita
summary: AN 6:42 Nāgita Sutta | To Nāgita — Another version of the story in 5:30, in which the Buddha delivers a stern rebuke to Ven. Nāgita, explaining why he is not attracted to “this slimy-excrement-pleasure, this torpor-pleasure, this pleasure of gains, offerings, & fame.”

title: AN 6:43 Nāga Sutta | On the Nāga
summary: AN 6:43 Nāga Sutta | On the Nāga — In the Buddha’s time, the term “nāga” was applied to any large being or tree, such as an elephant, a serpent, or a tree. In this sutta, though, the Buddha defines a nāga as anyone who does no misdeed in body, speech, or mind. Ven. Udāyin, inspired by the Buddha’s statement, composes a spontaneous poem, celebrating the arahant as the true nāga.

title: AN 6:45 Iṇa Sutta | Debt
summary: AN 6:45 Iṇa Sutta | Debt — The six miseries of a shameless monk compared to the six miseries of a person in debt.

title: AN 6:46 Cunda Sutta | Cunda
summary: AN 6:46 Cunda Sutta | Cunda — Ven. Mahā Cunda counsels the monks: “‘Being Dhamma-devotee monks, we will speak in praise of jhāna monks.’ That’s how you should train yourselves.… ‘Being jhāna monks, we will speak in praise of Dhamma-devotee monks.’ That’s how you should train yourselves.”

title: AN 6:47 Sandiṭṭhika Sutta | Visible Here & Now
summary: AN 6:47 Sandiṭṭhika Sutta | Visible Here & Now — The Buddha explains to a wanderer of another sect one way in which the Dhamma is visible here-&-now.

title: AN 6:49 Khema Sutta | With Khema
summary: AN 6:49 Khema Sutta | With Khema — Vens. Khema and Sumana declare their attainment of arahantship to the Buddha in impersonal terms, related to the ending of conceit.

title: AN 6:51 Ānanda Sutta | Ven. Ānanda
summary: AN 6:51 Ānanda Sutta | Ven. Ānanda — At Ven. Sāriputta’s request, Ven. Ānanda explains how a monk should practice so that he hears Dhamma he has not heard, so that the Dhammas he has heard do not get confused, so that the Dhammas he has touched with his awareness stay current, and so that he understands what previously was not understood.

title: AN 6:55 Soṇa Sutta | About Soṇa
summary: AN 6:55 Soṇa Sutta | About Soṇa — The famous simile of the lute.

title: AN 6:60 Citta Sutta | On Citta
summary: AN 6:60 Citta Sutta | On Citta — A monk, rebuked by Ven. Mahā Koṭṭhita disrobes, but later returns to the monkhood and becomes an arahant.

title: AN 6:61 Parāyana Sutta | The Further Shore
summary: AN 6:61 Parāyana Sutta | The Further Shore — A group of elder monks offer their interpretations of a line from a verse in Sn 5:2. The issue is then taken to the Buddha, who states that all six interpretations are valid, but then identifies which interpretation he had in mind when stating the verse.

title: AN 6:63 Nibbedhika Sutta | Penetrative
summary: AN 6:63 Nibbedhika Sutta | Penetrative — A thorough analysis of six topics: sensuality, feeling, perception, effluents, kamma, and stress.

title: AN 6:73 Jhāna Sutta | Jhāna (1)
summary: AN 6:73 Jhāna Sutta | Jhāna (1) — Six qualities that have to be abandoned before entering the first jhāna.

title: AN 6:74 Jhāna Sutta | Jhāna (2)
summary: AN 6:74 Jhāna Sutta | Jhāna (2) — Another list of six qualities that have to be abandoned before entering the first jhāna.

title: AN 6:85 Sīti Sutta | Cooled
summary: AN 6:85 Sīti Sutta | Cooled — Six activities that, when applied at the proper time to the training of the mind, make one capable of realizing unbinding.

title: AN 6:86 Āvaraṇatā Sutta | Obstructions
summary: AN 6:86 Āvaraṇatā Sutta | Obstructions — Six conditions that determine whether one will be capable of alighting on the True Dhamma while listening to the Dhamma.

title: AN 6:87 Kammāvaraṇatā Sutta | Kamma Obstructions
summary: AN 6:87 Kammāvaraṇatā Sutta | Kamma Obstructions — Another list of six conditions that determine whether one will be capable of alighting on the True Dhamma while listening to the Dhamma.

title: AN 6:88 Sussūsa Sutta | Listening Well
summary: AN 6:88 Sussūsa Sutta | Listening Well — Yet another list of six conditions that determine whether one will be capable of alighting on the True Dhamma while listening to the Dhamma.

title: AN 6:97 Ānisaṁsa Sutta | Rewards
summary: AN 6:97 Ānisaṁsa Sutta | Rewards — Six rewards in realizing the fruit of stream-entry

title: AN 6:102 Anodhi Sutta | Without Exception (1)
summary: AN 6:102 Anodhi Sutta | Without Exception (1) — The rewards of establishing the perception of inconstancy with regard to all fabrications without exception.

title: AN 6:103 Anodhi Sutta | Without Exception (2)
summary: AN 6:103 Anodhi Sutta | Without Exception (2) — The rewards of establishing the perception of stress with regard to all fabrications without exception.

title: AN 6:104 Anodhi Sutta | Without Exception (3)
summary: AN 6:104 Anodhi Sutta | Without Exception (3) — The rewards of establishing the perception of not-self with regard to all phenomena without exception.

title: AN 7:6 Dhana Sutta | Treasure
summary: AN 7:6 Dhana Sutta | Treasure — The noble treasures defined.

title: AN 7:7 Ugga Sutta | To Ugga
summary: AN 7:7 Ugga Sutta | To Ugga — The advantages of the noble treasures over treasures of silver and gold.

title: AN 7:11 Anusaya Sutta | Obsessions (1)
summary: AN 7:11 Anusaya Sutta | Obsessions (1) — Seven obsessions (anusaya).

title: AN 7:12 Anusaya Sutta | Obsessions (2)
summary: AN 7:12 Anusaya Sutta | Obsessions (2) — “With the abandoning & destruction of these seven obsessions, the holy life is fulfilled.”

title: AN 7:15 Udakupama Sutta | The Water Simile
summary: AN 7:15 Udakupama Sutta | The Water Simile — In a series of similes—ranging from a person who sinks down and stays sunk to a person who crosses over a flood and stands on high ground—the Buddha describes people in terms of how far they go with their grasp of the Dhamma.

title: AN 7:21 Bhikkhu-aparihāniya Sutta | Conditions for No Decline among the Monks
summary: AN 7:21 Bhikkhu-aparihāniya Sutta | Conditions for No Decline among the Monks — Seven conditions that will prevent the Saṅgha of monks from declining.

title: AN 7:31 Appamāda Sutta | Heedfulness
summary: AN 7:31 Appamāda Sutta | Heedfulness — Seven conditions that will keep an individual monk from declining.

title: AN 7:32 Hirimā Sutta | A Sense of Shame
summary: AN 7:32 Hirimā Sutta | A Sense of Shame — A slightly different list of seven conditions that will keep an individual monk from declining.

title: AN 7:33 Sovacassatā Sutta | Compliance (1)
summary: AN 7:33 Sovacassatā Sutta | Compliance (1) — Another list of seven conditions that will keep an individual monk from declining.

title: AN 7:34 Sovacassatā Sutta | Compliance (2)
summary: AN 7:34 Sovacassatā Sutta | Compliance (2) — Ven. Sāriputta expands on the list in the preceding sutta, showing that non-decline is not simply a matter of one’s own qualities, but also of encouraging others in the same qualities.

title: AN 7:35 Mitta Sutta | A Friend
summary: AN 7:35 Mitta Sutta | A Friend — Seven qualities of a loyal friend truly worth associating with.

title: AN 7:46 Saññā Sutta | Perceptions
summary: AN 7:46 Saññā Sutta | Perceptions — Seven perceptions that lead to the deathless.

title: AN 7:47 Methuna Sutta | Copulation
summary: AN 7:47 Methuna Sutta | Copulation — Seven activities that create “a gap, a break, a spot, a blemish of the holy life” even in one who doesn’t engage in sexual intercourse.

title: AN 7:48 Saññoga Sutta | Bondage
summary: AN 7:48 Saññoga Sutta | Bondage — How bondage to one’s own masculinity or femininity leads to bondage to others.

title: AN 7:49 Dāna Sutta | Giving
summary: AN 7:49 Dāna Sutta | Giving — The possible motivations for generosity and, in ascending order, the results they can lead to.

title: AN 7:50 Nandamātar Sutta | About Nandamātar
summary: AN 7:50 Nandamātar Sutta | About Nandamātar — The amazing qualities of one of the Buddha’s foremost female lay followers.

title: AN 7:51 Abyākata Sutta | Undeclared
summary: AN 7:51 Abyākata Sutta | Undeclared — Because a disciple of the noble ones sees views, the origination of views, the cessation of views, and the path of practice leading to the cessation of views, he/she sees no need to answer any of the ten undeclared questions.

title: AN 7:54 Sīha Sutta | To Sīha
summary: AN 7:54 Sīha Sutta | To Sīha — The rewards of giving.

title: AN 7:56 Kimila Sutta | To Kimila
summary: AN 7:56 Kimila Sutta | To Kimila — Reasons why, after the passing of the Buddha, the True Dhamma will or will not last a long time.

title: AN 7:58 Capala Sutta | Nodding
summary: AN 7:58 Capala Sutta | Nodding — The Buddha teaches Ven. Moggallāna (a) seven ways of shaking off drowsiness, (b) three attitudes to have toward others that will help promote concentration, and (c) how to be utterly free from bonds.

title: AN 7:60 Kodhana Sutta | An Angry Person
summary: AN 7:60 Kodhana Sutta | An Angry Person — Seven ways, pleasing to an enemy, in which you harm yourself when you are angry.

title: AN 7:63 Nagara Sutta | The Fortress
summary: AN 7:63 Nagara Sutta | The Fortress — In an extended metaphor, the Buddha compares the factors of the practice to a well-fortified fortress that can’t be undone by external foes or duplicitous allies.

title: AN 7:64 Dhammaññū Sutta | One With a Sense of Dhamma
summary: AN 7:64 Dhammaññū Sutta | One With a Sense of Dhamma — Seven qualities of a monk worthy of respect: having a sense of Dhamma, a sense of meaning, a sense of himself, a sense of moderation, a sense of time, a sense of social gatherings, and a sense of distinctions among individuals.

title: AN 7:70 Arakenānusasani Sutta | Araka’s Instructions
summary: AN 7:70 Arakenānusasani Sutta | Araka’s Instructions — The Buddha recalls the vivid teachings of Araka—who lived when the human life span was 60,000 years—counseling heedfulness because “next to nothing is the life of human beings.”

title: AN 7:80 Satthusāsana Sutta | The Teacher’s Instruction
summary: AN 7:80 Satthusāsana Sutta | The Teacher’s Instruction — The Buddha teaches Ven. Upāli seven ways of judging whether a dhamma—a teaching or an internal quality—is in line with the Dhamma and Vinaya.

title: AN 8:2 Paññā Sutta | Discernment
summary: AN 8:2 Paññā Sutta | Discernment — Eight conditions that lead to the arising and development of the discernment basic to the holy life.

title: AN 8:6 Lokavipatti Sutta | The Failings of the World
summary: AN 8:6 Lokavipatti Sutta | The Failings of the World — Eight worldly conditions: gain, loss, status, disgrace, censure, praise, pleasure, & pain. If you don’t reflect properly on them, welcoming the desirable and rebelling against the undesirable, they keep you from being released.

title: AN 8:7 Devadatta Sutta | About Devadatta
summary: AN 8:7 Devadatta Sutta | About Devadatta — Why it’s important for a monk to keep conquering, again and again, any arisen material gain, lack of material gain, status, lack of status, offerings, lack of offerings, evil ambition, and evil friendship.

title: AN 8:8 Uttara Sutta | About Uttara
summary: AN 8:8 Uttara Sutta | About Uttara — Sakka the deva-king teaches the preceding discourse to a monk who remembers only a small part of it.

title: AN 8:9 Nanda Sutta | About Nanda
summary: AN 8:9 Nanda Sutta | About Nanda — How the Buddha’s half-brother Nanda is able to follow the holy life even though he comes from a good family, is strong, good-looking, and fiercely passionate.

title: AN 8:13 Ājāññā Sutta | The Thoroughbred
summary: AN 8:13 Ājāññā Sutta | The Thoroughbred — Eight qualities of a good monk that parallel eight good qualities of a well-trained royal thoroughbred steed.

title: AN 8:14 Khaḷuṅka Sutta | Unruly
summary: AN 8:14 Khaḷuṅka Sutta | Unruly — Eight faults of an unruly monk that parallel eight faults of unruly horses.

title: AN 8:19 Pahārāda Sutta | Pahārāda
summary: AN 8:19 Pahārāda Sutta | Pahārāda — Eight ways in which the Dhamma and Vinaya are like the great ocean.

title: AN 8:22 Ugga Sutta | About Ugga
summary: AN 8:22 Ugga Sutta | About Ugga — The amazing qualities of one of the Buddha’s foremost male lay followers.

title: AN 8:23 Hatthaka Sutta | About Hatthaka (1)
summary: AN 8:23 Hatthaka Sutta | About Hatthaka (1) — The Buddha praises a wealthy lay follower for having eight qualities hard to find in a wealthy person.

title: AN 8:24 Hatthaka Sutta | About Hatthaka (2)
summary: AN 8:24 Hatthaka Sutta | About Hatthaka (2) — Hatthaka reports that he has won over a large following by using the grounds for the bonds of fellowship taught by the Buddha (see AN 4:32).

title: AN 8:26 Jīvaka Sutta | To Jīvaka (On Being a Lay Follower)
summary: AN 8:26 Jīvaka Sutta | To Jīvaka (On Being a Lay Follower) — Jivaka, the Buddha’s physician, asks the Buddha what qualifies one as a lay follower, a virtuous lay follower, and a lay follower who practices for his/her own benefit and the benefit of others.

title: AN 8:28 Bala Sutta | Strengths
summary: AN 8:28 Bala Sutta | Strengths — Eight strengths that allow you to know that the effluents are ended.

title: AN 8:30 Anuruddha Sutta | To Anuruddha
summary: AN 8:30 Anuruddha Sutta | To Anuruddha — The eight thoughts of a great person.

title: AN 8:39 Abhisanda Sutta | Bonanzas
summary: AN 8:39 Abhisanda Sutta | Bonanzas — Eight bonanzas of merit: taking refuge in the Triple Gem, and adhering to the five precepts in all situations.

title: AN 8:40 Vipāka Sutta | Results
summary: AN 8:40 Vipāka Sutta | Results — The specific results that come from breaking each of the five precepts or engaging in the various forms of wrong speech.

title: AN 8:51 Gotamī Sutta | To Gotamī
summary: AN 8:51 Gotamī Sutta | To Gotamī — The founding of the order of nuns.

title: AN 8:53 Saṅkhitta Sutta | In Brief
summary: AN 8:53 Saṅkhitta Sutta | In Brief — An important sutta in which the Buddha teaches Mahā Pajāpati eight ways of judging whether a dhamma—a teaching or an internal quality—is in line with the Dhamma and Vinaya.

title: AN 8:54 Dīghajāṇu Sutta | To Dīghajāṇu
summary: AN 8:54 Dīghajāṇu Sutta | To Dīghajāṇu — Four qualities that lead to happiness in this life, four qualities that drain one’s wealth, and four qualities that lead to happiness in the next life.

title: AN 8:61 Icchā Sutta | Desire
summary: AN 8:61 Icchā Sutta | Desire — How the desire for material gain—such as for food, clothing, shelter, or medicine—may or may not lead a monk to fall from the True Dhamma.

title: AN 8:70 Saṅkhitta Sutta | In Brief (Sublime Attitudes, Mindfulness, & Concentration)
summary: AN 8:70 Saṅkhitta Sutta | In Brief (Sublime Attitudes, Mindfulness, & Concentration) — An elderly monk asks for a brief teaching that he can then use when practicing alone. The Buddha teaches him eight concentration practices, developing the jhāna factors based on the four brahmavihāras and the four establishings of mindfulness.

title: AN 8:71 Gayā Sutta | At Gayā
summary: AN 8:71 Gayā Sutta | At Gayā — The Buddha discusses the eight stages in which he developed the knowledge of devas that constituted part of his awakening.

title: AN 8:95 Kusīta-Ārabbhavatthu Sutta | The Grounds for Laziness & the Arousal of Energy
summary: AN 8:95 Kusīta-Ārabbhavatthu Sutta | The Grounds for Laziness & the Arousal of Energy — A humorous sutta showing how the eight situations that a lazy monk will use as excuses for staying lazy are the same eight situations that an energetic monk will use as motivation for being energetic.

title: AN 8:103 Yasa Sutta | Honor
summary: AN 8:103 Yasa Sutta | Honor — A longer version of the story in 5:30 and 6:42, in which the Buddha delivers a stern rebuke to Ven. Nāgita, explaining why he is not attracted to “this slimy-excrement-pleasure, this torpor-pleasure, this pleasure of gains, offerings, & fame.”

title: AN 9:1 Sambodhi Sutta | Self-awakening
summary: AN 9:1 Sambodhi Sutta | Self-awakening — Nine prerequisites for developing the wings to self-awakening.

title: AN 9:7 Sutavā Sutta | To Sutavant
summary: AN 9:7 Sutavā Sutta | To Sutavant — Nine principles that an arahant cannot transgress.

title: AN 9:8 Sajjha Sutta | To Sajjha
summary: AN 9:8 Sajjha Sutta | To Sajjha — Another set of nine principles that an arahant cannot transgress.

title: AN 9:13 Koṭṭhita Sutta | With Koṭṭhita
summary: AN 9:13 Koṭṭhita Sutta | With Koṭṭhita — Ven. Mahā Koṭṭhita quizzes Ven. Sāriputta as to the purpose of the holy life lived under the Buddha.

title: AN 9:14 Samiddhi Sutta | About Samiddhi
summary: AN 9:14 Samiddhi Sutta | About Samiddhi — Ven. Sāriputta quizzes a junior monk about thoughts and resolves: What is their basis? How do they go to multiplicity? What is their origination, meeting place, presiding state, governing principle, surpassing state, heartwood? Where to they gain a footing?

title: AN 9:15 Gaṇḍa Sutta | A Boil
summary: AN 9:15 Gaṇḍa Sutta | A Boil — The body compared to an oozing boil.

title: AN 9:16 Saññā Sutta | Perceptions
summary: AN 9:16 Saññā Sutta | Perceptions — Nine perceptions that lead to the deathless.

title: AN 9:20 Velāma Sutta | About Velāma
summary: AN 9:20 Velāma Sutta | About Velāma — The Buddha tells of a great offering he made in a previous lifetime, but then goes on to tell how goodwill and the perception of inconstancy are much more fruitful than the most fruitful gift possible.

title: AN 9:24 Sattā Sutta | Beings
summary: AN 9:24 Sattā Sutta | Beings — The different levels of the cosmos where beings may take rebirth.

title: AN 9:25 Paññā Sutta | Discernment
summary: AN 9:25 Paññā Sutta | Discernment — The qualities of an arahant’s mind.

title: AN 9:31 Anupubbanirodha Sutta | Step-by-step Cessation
summary: AN 9:31 Anupubbanirodha Sutta | Step-by-step Cessation — What ceases, step by step, as one goes progressively through the nine concentration attainments.

title: AN 9:32 Vihāra Sutta | Dwellings (1)
summary: AN 9:32 Vihāra Sutta | Dwellings (1) — The nine concentration attainments listed.

title: AN 9:33 Vihāra Sutta | Dwellings (2)
summary: AN 9:33 Vihāra Sutta | Dwellings (2) — The nine concentration attainments defined.

title: AN 9:34 Nibbāna Sutta | Unbinding
summary: AN 9:34 Nibbāna Sutta | Unbinding — Ven. Sāriputta explains how unbinding is pleasant even though nothing is felt there.

title: AN 9:35 Gāvī Sutta | The Cow
summary: AN 9:35 Gāvī Sutta | The Cow — Using the simile of the foolish, inexperienced cow, the Buddha shows why it is wise to establish oneself well in a concentration attainment before trying to move on to the next one. When these attainments are well mastered in this way, they lead to the six higher knowledges whenever there is an opening.

title: AN 9:36 Jhāna Sutta | Mental Absorption
summary: AN 9:36 Jhāna Sutta | Mental Absorption — How awakening is attained by mastering any of the first seven of the nine concentration attainments and then reflecting on that attainment, analyzing it in terms of the five aggregates.

title: AN 9:37 Ānanda Sutta | With Ānanda
summary: AN 9:37 Ānanda Sutta | With Ānanda — The levels of concentration—the first three formless attainments and the concentration that is the fruit of arahantship—in which one is not percipient of the five physical senses even though they are present, and yet one is nevertheless percipient.

title: AN 9:38 Brāhmaṇa Sutta | To Two Brahmans
summary: AN 9:38 Brāhmaṇa Sutta | To Two Brahmans — The Buddha describes how a person in the first eight of the concentration attainments comes to the end of the cosmos, defined as the five strings of sensuality. Only by gaining discernment, though, does one cross over attachment to the cosmos.

title: AN 9:39 Deva Sutta | The Devas (About Jhāna)
summary: AN 9:39 Deva Sutta | The Devas (About Jhāna) — How—through the practice of concentration—to keep secluded from Māra, how to become invisible to Māra, and how to cross over attachment to the cosmos.

title: AN 9:40 Nāga Sutta | The Tusker
summary: AN 9:40 Nāga Sutta | The Tusker — A humorous sutta in which a monk in the nine concentration attainments is compared to an elephant who, going off into seclusion from the bustle of the herd, scratches himself with a branch to allay his itch.

title: AN 9:41 Tapussa Sutta | To Tapussa (On Renunciation)
summary: AN 9:41 Tapussa Sutta | To Tapussa (On Renunciation) — How the Buddha, prior to his awakening, was able to overcome his reluctance to renounce sensuality and the pleasures of the lower concentration attainments.

title: AN 9:42 Pañcāla Sutta | Pañcāla’s Verse
summary: AN 9:42 Pañcāla Sutta | Pañcāla’s Verse — Ven. Ānanda explains a verse spoken by a deva on the topic of jhāna.

title: AN 9:43 Kāyasakkhī Sutta | Bodily Witness*
summary: AN 9:43 Kāyasakkhī Sutta | Bodily Witness* — Ven. Ānanda defines a “bodily witness” as one who remains “touching with his/her body” all nine concentration attainments and sees with discernment on emerging from the ninth.

title: AN 9:44 Paññāvimutti Sutta | Released through Discernment*
summary: AN 9:44 Paññāvimutti Sutta | Released through Discernment* — Ven. Ānanda defines a person “released through discernment” as one who gains release through developing discernment based on any of the nine concentration attainments.

title: AN 9:45 Ubhatobhāga Sutta | (Released) Both Ways*
summary: AN 9:45 Ubhatobhāga Sutta | (Released) Both Ways* — Ven. Ānanda defines a person “released both ways” as one who remains “touching with his/her body” and seeing with discernment any of the nine concentration attainments.

title: AN 9:62 Bhabba Sutta | Capable
summary: AN 9:62 Bhabba Sutta | Capable — Nine qualities that have to been abandoned for reaching arahantship.

title: AN 9:63 Sikkhā-dubbalya Sutta | Things That Weaken the Training
summary: AN 9:63 Sikkhā-dubbalya Sutta | Things That Weaken the Training — To break the five precepts weakens the training. To abandon the actions that weaken the training, develop the four establishings of mindfulness.

title: AN 9:64 Nīvaraṇa Sutta | Hindrances
summary: AN 9:64 Nīvaraṇa Sutta | Hindrances — To abandon the five hindrances, develop the four establishings of mindfulness.

title: AN 10:6 Samādhi Sutta | Concentration
summary: AN 10:6 Samādhi Sutta | Concentration — The Buddha—asked to describe an attainment of concentration in which one is not percipient of the physical properties, the formless attainments, this world or the next world, and yet one is still percipient—replies.

title: AN 10:7 Sāriputta Sutta | With Sāriputta
summary: AN 10:7 Sāriputta Sutta | With Sāriputta — Ven. Sāriputta gives a slightly different response to the question asked in the preceding sutta.

title: AN 10:13 Saṁyojana Sutta | Fetters
summary: AN 10:13 Saṁyojana Sutta | Fetters — The ten fetters listed.

title: AN 10:15 Appamāda Sutta | Heedfulness
summary: AN 10:15 Appamāda Sutta | Heedfulness — Ten similes making the point that heedfulness is the root of all skillful qualities and the foremost among them.

title: AN 10:17 Nātha Sutta | Protectors (1)
summary: AN 10:17 Nātha Sutta | Protectors (1) — Ten qualities by which you create a protector for yourself.

title: AN 10:18 Nātha Sutta | Protectors (2)
summary: AN 10:18 Nātha Sutta | Protectors (2) — You create protection for yourself by acting in ways that inspire others to offer you instruction.

title: AN 10:20 Ariyāvāsa Sutta | Dwellings of the Noble Ones
summary: AN 10:20 Ariyāvāsa Sutta | Dwellings of the Noble Ones — Ten noble dwellings for the mind.

title: AN 10:24 Cunda Sutta | Cunda
summary: AN 10:24 Cunda Sutta | Cunda — Even if you can talk about the Dhamma, if you are overcome by greed. aversion, delusion, anger, hostility, hypocrisy, spite, selfishness, evil envy, or evil longing, you are still a pauper in the Dhamma.

title: AN 10:29 Kosala Sutta | The Kosalan
summary: AN 10:29 Kosala Sutta | The Kosalan — Like supremacy in the human and deva worlds, exalted states of mind—even experiences of all-encompassing white light and non-dual consciousness—are all subject to change and aberration. In this sutta the Buddha offers a series of contemplations for inducing disenchantment and dispassion for even the most supreme things in the cosmos.

title: AN 10:46 Sakka Sutta | To the Sakyans (on the Uposatha)
summary: AN 10:46 Sakka Sutta | To the Sakyans (on the Uposatha) — The Buddha explains to his relatives why the bliss that comes from earning a wage is next to nothing when compared to the bliss that comes from sacrificing one’s work on the uposatha day to observe the eight precepts.

title: AN 10:48 Dasa Dhamma Sutta | Ten Things
summary: AN 10:48 Dasa Dhamma Sutta | Ten Things — Ten things that a person gone-forth should reflect on often.

title: AN 10:51 Sacitta Sutta | One’s Own Mind
summary: AN 10:51 Sacitta Sutta | One’s Own Mind — Even if you can’t read the minds of others, you should train yourself to read your own mind—and to respond properly to any defilements you read there.

title: AN 10:54 Samatha Sutta | Tranquility
summary: AN 10:54 Samatha Sutta | Tranquility — The same message as the preceding sutta, but expressed in terms of the development of tranquility and insight.

title: AN 10:58 Mūla Sutta | Rooted
summary: AN 10:58 Mūla Sutta | Rooted — What is the root of all phenomena? Where do they gain a footing? What is their end?

title: AN 10:60 Girimānanda Sutta | To Girimānanda
summary: AN 10:60 Girimānanda Sutta | To Girimānanda — The Buddha has Ven. Ānanda instruct Ven. Girimānanda—who is ill—on ten perceptions that heal body and mind. Interestingly, mindfulness of breathing is listed as one of the perceptions.

title: AN 10:61 Avijjā Sutta | Ignorance
summary: AN 10:61 Avijjā Sutta | Ignorance — Even though no past beginning point for ignorance can be discerned, it is still possible to feed it—or to starve it—in the present.

title: AN 10:69 Kathāvatthu Sutta | Topics of Conversation (1)
summary: AN 10:69 Kathāvatthu Sutta | Topics of Conversation (1) — Encountering a group of monks who have been engaged in worldly conversation, the Buddha teaches them the topics that they should be talking about.

title: AN 10:70 Kathāvatthu Sutta | Topics of Conversation (2)
summary: AN 10:70 Kathāvatthu Sutta | Topics of Conversation (2) — Another lesson in right conversation. Not only should you talk about good qualities, but you should also develop them in yourself.

title: AN 10:71 Ākaṅkha Sutta | Wishes
summary: AN 10:71 Ākaṅkha Sutta | Wishes — Ten reasons, of ascending worth, for perfecting the precepts and being committed to the development of tranquility (samatha) and insight (vipassanā).

title: AN 10:72 Kaṇṭhaka Sutta | Thorns
summary: AN 10:72 Kaṇṭhaka Sutta | Thorns — Ten “thorns” that create difficulties for the practice.

title: AN 10:73 Iṭṭhā Sutta | Wished For
summary: AN 10:73 Iṭṭhā Sutta | Wished For — How to obtain what is welcome but hard to obtain in the world.

title: AN 10:75 Migāsālāya Sutta | About Migāsālā
summary: AN 10:75 Migāsālāya Sutta | About Migāsālā — Why you shouldn’t try to measure the attainments of other individuals. (The implicit message here: Pay more attention to your own attainment.)

title: AN 10:76 Abhabba Sutta | Incapable
summary: AN 10:76 Abhabba Sutta | Incapable — Things that have to be abandoned in order to be free of birth, aging, and death.

title: AN 10:80 Āghāta Sutta | Hatred
summary: AN 10:80 Āghāta Sutta | Hatred — Ten ways of subduing hatred.

title: AN 10:81 Vāhuna Sutta | To Vāhuna
summary: AN 10:81 Vāhuna Sutta | To Vāhuna — Released from ten things, the Tathāgata dwells with unrestricted awareness.

title: AN 10:92 Vera Sutta | Animosity
summary: AN 10:92 Vera Sutta | Animosity — Ten conditions for knowing if you are a streamwinner.

title: AN 10:93 Diṭṭhi Sutta | Views
summary: AN 10:93 Diṭṭhi Sutta | Views — Anāthapiṇḍika explains to a group of sectarians why right view is a special form of view: Holding to other views, one is holding to stress, but using right view enables you to see the escape even from right view.

title: AN 10:94 Vajjiya Sutta | About Vajjiya
summary: AN 10:94 Vajjiya Sutta | About Vajjiya — Confronted by sectarians who accuse the Buddha of being a nihilist, one who doesn’t declare anything, Vajjiya counters that the Buddha does declare two things: what’s skillful and what’s not.

title: AN 10:95 Uttiya Sutta | To Uttiya
summary: AN 10:95 Uttiya Sutta | To Uttiya — After learning why the Buddha doesn’t take a stance on the ten declared questions, Uttiya asks him what percentage of the cosmos will be led by his teaching to release. The Buddha remains silent; Ven. Ānanda takes Uttiya aside and, using the simile of the wise gatekeeper, explains why.

title: AN 10:96 Kokanuda Sutta | To Kokanuda (On Viewpoints)
summary: AN 10:96 Kokanuda Sutta | To Kokanuda (On Viewpoints) — A wanderer, addressing Ven. Ānanda without knowing that it’s him, asks why the Buddha doesn’t take a stance on the ten undeclared questions.

title: AN 10:99 Upāli Sutta | To Upāli
summary: AN 10:99 Upāli Sutta | To Upāli — Using the simile of the rabbit or cat that thinks it can imitate an elephant, the Buddha discourages Ven. Upāli from living in the forest, and encourages him instead to stay living with the Saṅgha.

title: AN 10:101 Samaṇasaññā Sutta | Contemplative Perceptions
summary: AN 10:101 Samaṇasaññā Sutta | Contemplative Perceptions — Three perceptions that contemplatives should always hold in mind, and the seven rewards of doing so.

title: AN 10:103 Micchatta Sutta | Wrongness
summary: AN 10:103 Micchatta Sutta | Wrongness — How wrong view gives rise to other forms of wrongness.

title: AN 10:104 Bīja Sutta | The Seed
summary: AN 10:104 Bīja Sutta | The Seed — Using the similes of the bitter seed and sweet seed, the Buddha explains how wrong view gives rise to other forms of wrongness, and right view to other forms of rightness.

title: AN 10:108 Tikicchā Sutta | A Purgative
summary: AN 10:108 Tikicchā Sutta | A Purgative — The right factors of the arahants tenfold path purge away the corresponding wrong factors.

title: AN 10:118 Orima Sutta | The Near Shore
summary: AN 10:118 Orima Sutta | The Near Shore — In many discourses, the Buddha speaks of the near shore and the far shore. In this discourse he explains the near shore as the ten factors of the wrong path, and the far shore as the ten factors of the right. For another explanation of “near shore” and “far shore,” see SN 35:197 and Sn 5.

title: AN 10:165 Cunda Kammāraputta Sutta | To Cunda the Silversmith
summary: AN 10:165 Cunda Kammāraputta Sutta | To Cunda the Silversmith — The Buddha explains to Cunda the silversmith—who later offered him his last meal—that purification is a matter, not of rites, but of following the ten courses of good conduct: three bodily, four verbal, and three mental.

title: AN 10:166 Jāṇussoṇin Sutta | To Jāṇussoṇin (On Offerings to the Dead)
summary: AN 10:166 Jāṇussoṇin Sutta | To Jāṇussoṇin (On Offerings to the Dead) — A brahman asks: When the merit of a gift is dedicated to the deceased, do they receive that merit? The Buddha explains that they do if they are hungry ghosts, but then goes on to state that—better than following the course of action leading to rebirth as a hungry ghost, and there waiting for dedications of merit—one should follow the course of action leading to rebirth in heaven, where one can enjoy the fruits of the gifts that one gave in this lifetime.

title: AN 10:196 Brahmavihāra Sutta | The Sublime Attitudes
summary: AN 10:196 Brahmavihāra Sutta | The Sublime Attitudes — The rewards of practicing the sublime abidings.

title: AN 11:1 Kimattha Sutta | What is the Purpose?
summary: AN 11:1 Kimattha Sutta | What is the Purpose? — Beginning with skillful virtues, and ascending all the way through dispassion, the Buddha discusses the purpose and reward of different aspects of the practice, showing how the more basic parts of the practice have the higher ones as their reward.

title: AN 11:2 Cetanā Sutta | An Act of Will
summary: AN 11:2 Cetanā Sutta | An Act of Will — How the more basic parts of the practice lead naturally to the higher ones.

title: AN 11:10 Sandha Sutta | To Sandha
summary: AN 11:10 Sandha Sutta | To Sandha — Using the simile of the thoughts that absorb a thoroughbred horse as opposed to the thoughts that absorb an unbroken colt, the Buddha describes the jhāna of an arahant as opposed to the “jhāna” of one who has not found escape from the five hindrances.

title: AN 11:12 Mahānāma Sutta | To Mahānāma (1)
summary: AN 11:12 Mahānāma Sutta | To Mahānāma (1) — When the Buddha and the monks prepare to leave at the end of the Rains retreat, Mahānāma—a streamwinner—asks the Buddha what he should meditate on in their absence. The Buddha advises developing the five strengths and practicing recollection of six things: the Buddha, the Dhamma, the Saṅgha, his own virtue, his own generosity, and the virtues of the devas that are found within him.

title: AN 11:13 Mahānāma Sutta | To Mahānāma (2)
summary: AN 11:13 Mahānāma Sutta | To Mahānāma (2) — The same situation and question as in the preceding sutta, with the same answer expressed in slightly different terms.

title: AN 11:16 Mettā Sutta | Goodwill
summary: AN 11:16 Mettā Sutta | Goodwill — The eleven rewards of developing goodwill as an awareness release.
